entry.title: Weeknotes-002
entry.content:
What a month that week was! I‚Äôve been in really busy in final delivery for my current project at work so haven‚Äôt had a huge amount of time to work on this blog. I had planned to start making another post looking at composition of shots and what goes in to them, that‚Äôll come soon. I have found some time to learn a bit more CSS and tinkering around with different ways to present images on this website. I updated my last post about Psycho to have the lines overlay and fade over the original image now rather than sit below it which I think is a neater presentation and keeps the post a bit smaller without impacting performance on the site as it‚Äôs all just a bit of simple, vanilla CSS.

With the sad, inevitable slow down in post production that will be coming our way due to most worldwide filming pausing for C-19 I‚Äôll hopefully get a bit more time over the summer to work on other hobbies.

(Un)real Engine

Well at least we know what the next Tomb Raider is going to look like. Whilst of course so much of what is seen in this demo is down to the wizard and not the wand, the technology on display here leaves me in awe of what is now possible (as long as you have a few TB spare on your hard drive). Realtime lighting has always been a far off dream in VFX (I‚Äôm still yet to see katana able to put a checkerboard on a plane and do real time lighting). Of course, there are tricks in play here that perhaps wouldn‚Äôt really stand up to photoreal scrutiny, but I would still take this over a 4 hour+ render any day when it can be tweaked further in comp with the right passes. Lifting the polygon limit, as they claim here, I think still needs some looking at if it‚Äôs really true - this has been one of the problems with using game engines in VFX in the past.

If this is really a true demo using realistic (as in reasonably sized) assets and textures (and I think it‚Äôs a big if at the moment) then it‚Äôs a genuine game changer. I imagine this 5 minute demo might be taking 500GB+, but still it‚Äôs beautiful‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll hopefully give this a go one of these days and see what it can do.

Anyone who knows my gaming habits knows Tomb Raider is my absolute favourite all time franchise - pleeeease let the next TR game look even half as good as this!

Watching

Not much time to watch TV this week being in delivery on my current project(s) but I fancied a couple of familiar movies that I‚Äôd seen a few times and didn‚Äôt have to concentrate on too much; Seven and Ocean‚Äôs 11.

Gaming

I did manage to steal a few minutes to try and pick Fallout 4 back up. I‚Äôd put a lot of time in to the game before Christmas and felt like i‚Äôd kind of done everything in the base game (I‚Äôm sure I haven‚Äôt though) so the world felt a little bit empty overall. Maybe I‚Äôll pick up the season pass and play some of the DLC; Far Harbour is supposed to be a great expansion.

On the back of that Fallout 4 failure I‚Äôve fired up my PS3 again and will have a go at Fallout: New Vegas. I played a bit before but never completed the main story for one reason or another. I‚Äôm loving this world at the moment though so hopefully I can give it a better shot this time.

Around the Web

  • We should be very wary of the R value

The R0 rate is apparently climbing back to near 1 in many places. This is an easy headline for media to report how everything is burning down, but closer analysis of this means R0 climbing a bit is actually a good thing and showing that the lockdown is working. This is due to an interesting quirk of statistics called Simpson‚Äôs Paradox.

entry.title: Weeknotes 001
entry.content:
I‚Äôve decided to start keeping ‚Äòweeknotes‚Äô. One of the best things to come out of this whole C-19 tragedy has been an opportunity to spend time on personal projects and i‚Äôve been reading a lot more blogs, as well as having time to work more on this one. I‚Äôve been particularly following programmers blogs as they seem to be the most easy to find and, frankly, the most numerous.

Whilst I have little skill and knowledge in programming languages and the advanced technical discussions that take place on many of them is sadly lost on me, I have really enjoyed reading some of the more accessible ones that discuss more general topics about technology, their lives and interests outside of programming.

Many of the more active blogs post a weekly diary of things they‚Äôve discovered over the past 7 days. What they‚Äôre working on and interesting links and articles from across the web. I think it‚Äôs a good practice to get in to - it encourages you to actually do some stuff in the week to have something to write about if nothing else!

In the current climate it‚Äôs important to keep busy and try and be productive where you can and I think keeping a record of what you‚Äôve done, uncovered, and perhaps even missed, is a great thing to do. I‚Äôve committed to trying to become a more active producer rather than passive consumer.

The New Normal

I‚Äôm not sure I have anything unique or articulate to say about Covid-19 except that I miss going out for food. I can live without the social interaction better than I imagined. I don‚Äôt particularly miss the old routines of my life, and I certainly don‚Äôt miss the commute to work and office life. But I do miss a properly cooked wood-fired pizza. Selfish with everything else going on in the world, I know. I miss dumplings, a proper bowl of ramen and ordering 4 different types of tacos. I‚Äôm going to eat out so much when all this is over.

Somehow this still doesn‚Äôt all seem real, maybe I‚Äôm incredibly lucky to be able to think this way - I‚Äôve not had any personal tragedies or even known anyone who has had this thing. I only hope it stays that way.

I‚Äôm increasingly turned off by this phrase ‚ÄòThe New Normal‚Äò. Police patrolling public spaces, fining people for getting exercise cannot be the new normal. Now, more than ever, in these unprecedented times, as we realize that we‚Äôre all in this together, standing side by side* this cannot be the new normal. Read 1984 and be the change, y‚Äôall.

*but still 6 feet apart

Watching

On the recommendation of a friend I watched ‚ÄòThe Night Of‚Äô. It was amazing. Truly one of the best short series I‚Äôve ever watched. The story is gripping, the acting is perfectly cast (so rare), with fantastic performances from Michael K. Williams and Riz Ahmed in particular. The real winner for me was the cinematography however. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve seen a TV show that was filmed so ‚Äòlavishly‚Äô for a while and the way it was all shot added so much to the scenes and elevated the story. Highly recommended.

Gaming

I downloaded Farming Simulator 19 as it was one of the PS Plus games of the month. I lasted about 30 minutes. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs a good game for that niche market and refreshing change from so many run of the mill action adventures, but I just haven‚Äôt got the level of concentration at the moment to play it with everything else going on.

I‚Äôve been playing a lot of 2 olddddd games I used to play in my teens called Pharaoh and Empire:Rise of the Middle Kingdom. They‚Äôre super chill, city builder time wasters, just what the doctor ordered right now. You can pick them up on GoG for pennies.

Around the Web

  • Find Twitch streamers who have no one watching them!
    https://twitchroulette.net

  • 2020 Pulitzer prize winners announced
    https://www.pulitzer.org/news/announcement-2020-pulitzer-prize-winners

I haven‚Äôt read most of these, but if you only read one, make it this. Ben Taub‚Äôs examination of the relationship between a Guantanamo guard and his prisoner is a fascinating, if sad, read. Long, but worth your time.

  • For 32 Years, This Japanese Chef Has Been Making a Painting of Every Single Meal He Eats.
    https://news.artnet.com/art-world/itsuo-kobayashi-1787082

Thought of the Week

I bet Marie Kondo wishes she had more shit in her house right about now.

entry.title: Analysing Composition #1: The Lines of Psycho
entry.content:
As interesting as my taco recipes are this is supposed to be a blog about film and the craft of making films. I‚Äôve been thinking about doing a series of blog posts on this subject for a while but couldn‚Äôt find the right angle that I wanted to explore.

I often remark in my job as a VFX supervisor how sometimes shots just ‚Äòdon‚Äôt work‚Äô. They‚Äôre sometimes not well executed. Sometimes they‚Äôre not well planned or haven‚Äôt come together in the right way in the end. It‚Äôs hard to explain why and this is often my fault in not sculpting the visual effects for a shot in the right way, but sometimes the shot itself is unfortunately poorly conceived from the beginning. This is no criticism of the Director of Photography or Director; there are a million reasons why a shot might not work.

I‚Äôve been a long time fan of the work of director Alfred Hitchcock. He was a master of shot-making and composition and it‚Äôs hard to find an example of a shot in one of his movies that doesn‚Äôt work. He used to plan out the details of the entire movie he was making, right down to the focal length and lens he would use to film each shot, well before the project began filming. Watching Hitchcock‚Äôs movies is watching a masterclass in film making and I particularly admire his skills of shot composition.

I‚Äôd like to try in this first blog post (in what I hope will be a series) to explain a bit about the process of film making and learn more myself along the way. What makes a shot work, or not, and why? By analyzing an example from the great man himself I‚Äôll try and explain why his films are so well composed visually.

Note: This post inevitably contains spoilers. If you haven‚Äôt watched Psycho before stop reading now and please go and watch it immediately. It‚Äôs one of the all-time great thrillers of cinema.

Lines are everywhere

When designing a shot a good director will make sure that you are looking at exactly what they want you to be looking at. It might sound obvious when put like that but it‚Äôs harder than it might appear to focus the attention of the audience. Every shot is another piece of the jigsaw puzzle of their movie and there is no room for wasted elements or a shot that misses its mark. To do this, a good shot needs a skeleton to build on. The lines of a shot are that skeleton and must be well constructed.

Used correctly lines can convey a feeling of calm or of fear, they can impart a sense of strength and power or make a shot more playful and organic. Even the same source material composed differently can lead the lines of a shot to have a completely different feeling and tell a different story to the audience.

The very opening titles of Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs Psycho are full of lines.



The very first shot of the movie is just a series of horizontal lines. Horizontal lines sit in complete harmony with the longest edges of the frame and are often used to convey a sense of passive calm. We associate them with wide-open spaces, peaceful ocean horizons. Someone lying horizontally is passive, no threat. However, in this case, they‚Äôre staggered and, combined with Bernard Herrmann‚Äôs chilling violin score, they create a sense of disharmony, frenzy, and unease.

Hitchcock follows up with a shot of vertical lines. Vertical lines are defiant. They defy gravity and they stand tall. They tower over us and remind us of strong, immovable objects like trees, walls and buildings. A vertical line through an image can create a barrier between objects. They allow us to explore up and down an image, but often too, they can reframe the sides of an image and center our focus to what lies between them in way that horizontal lines do not.

As the opening sequence progresses we‚Äôre shown these two elements competing with each other, becoming more and more disordered. A perfect, simple, introduction to a movie called Psycho.

From the opening credits we move to shots over the city of Pheonix, AZ. Plenty of vertical lines to admire before we arrive at this shot:

Horizontal lines are often used to let our eyes move around the image from side to side without wandering too far off-axis but can present quite a boring image if there isn‚Äôt a lot else to look at. An image of a window with horizontal blinds presented square to camera and flatly lit doesn‚Äôt give you much to look at or a desire to explore further.

Hitchcock chooses to slightly angle the camera approach to the window to create a more interesting composition. This is the first diagonal or ‚Äòoff square‚Äô line we‚Äôre shown in the movie. Combined with the shadows also at an angle it‚Äôs an intriguing image that invites us to explore further and want to know what‚Äôs on the other side of that window.

Diagonal lines often create a sense of imbalance and disorder, that is if they don‚Äôt have a dominant orientation. With a dominant or consistent orientation like we see here, they can be a powerful tool to lead the eye. In the case of this window, the angle of the shadow from the bottom right corner towards the center of frame and the bottom left corner shadow from the window ledge achieve the same thing. They lead our eye inside the window. The darkness in the room reveals nothing initially and leaves us wanting to know what‚Äôs inside.

The 30-day film

Psycho was a film that nearly never got made. When Hitchcock informed his studio, Paramount, that the title to his next picture was going to be called *‚ÄùPsycho‚Äù* they didn‚Äôt like it. They first tried to dissuade him by lowering the film‚Äôs budget and then by informing him that all the studio‚Äôs stages were fully booked around the time he wanted to shoot. Undeterred he decided to take the lower budget, film in black and white to save costs and moved production down the road to Universal Studios. The whole film was shot in just 30 days. The no-frills approach to the project seemed to suit him, The New York Times quoted him in a later interview as saying

Nothing about it to distract from telling the tale, just like the old days.

Lines must be carefully placed

Understanding how the orientation of lines in a frame affect its mood is a useful tool for storytelling but it needs to be combined with good placement as well. Badly placed lines can have negative effects on the composition of an image.

Lines that divide a frame in two down the center draw strong attention to that which is in the middle of frame, it‚Äôs a good way to get focus the audience on what you want them to look at. Something of a trademark shot for Alfred Hitchcock are his full-frame portrait shots of characters. By this point in the film we‚Äôve followed Marion Crane (played by Janet Leigh) as she‚Äôs stolen money from her employer to start a new life with her boyfriend in Los Angeles.

The placement of lines in this shot draws your attention to her eyes and the full range of emotions going on inside her as she wrestles with whether she‚Äôs done the right thing.

A shot composed off-center or from the side wouldn‚Äôt have the same impact visually. It might be useful to tell more about where she is in relation to the landscape or other such details. The point of this sequence of shots framed this way however is to have us focus on her. Framing Marion this way with other lines in the scene guiding us back towards her when we might be wandering elsewhere works perfectly. Framing her eyes at the same level as the horizon ensures that even when we scan around the shot, the horizontal line of the horizon leads us back to her eyes. The sides of the road do the same thing.

The placement of lines in a scene can also be a powerful way to show subliminal moments happening between characters. Lines at the edges of frame can push two characters closer together in a romance, say, or in the case of the shot below, they put up a visual wall between people to imply a barrier between them. A barrier perhaps that one person will not, or cannot, cross.

Learn the rules so you know how to break them

‚ÄúThe rule of thirds‚Äù is a well known composition technique that places lines of interest at 1/3 and 2/3 positions of height or width within the frame. It‚Äôs a harmonious relationship that suits the eye comfortably and is very often used. Subverting this by dividing through the center of frame is a powerful way to create shots with an odd feeling or that something is wrong and can help create tension. Used incorrectly though it can create a monotonous framing that lacks interest.

There is also an implied line in most shots that we never notice; that being the diagonal from one corner to the other. This can be useful to connect items and particularly works well in combination with the rule of thirds to bring together the two sides of an image that you‚Äôve laid down from upper 1/3 to lower 1/3. Here in this shot, Marion‚Äôs (and the audience‚Äôs) attention is brought back to the newspaper in her handbag that she realizes she can use to hide the stolen money. The shot is well framed to make this connection easy to read.

The rule of thirds is quite often used in conversation sequences. You just place each character at 1/3 spacing and the natural, harmonious framing makes for an easy on the eye composition that‚Äôs not too distracting in other ways. Breaking this relationship in a conversation even for just a shot or two is a clever way to give an otherwise comfortable conversation a moment of tension.

Here Norman Bates (played by Anthony Hopkins) is framed at 1/3 from the right and the conversation is charming and easy, but as Marion explores his relationship with his mother it takes a direction he doesn‚Äôt like and he leans forward. Moving his framing to center screen focuses our attention on him more, creates a stronger image that concentrates the hostility and a makes for an unsettling, tense moment. The tension is released when he leans back, smiles and the conversation returns to a lighter tone with its usual rule of thirds framing.

The Zen of Lines

The ‚Äúshower scene‚Äù in Psycho is one of the greatest moments of cinema. It‚Äôs less than a minute long but took 7 days to film. When it was shown in theatres, audiences at the time were shocked that the leading actress could be murdered not even 1/2 of the way through the movie. It had never been done in such a way and it gave Psycho it‚Äôs ‚Äúword of mouth‚Äù reputation that made it the must-see movie, one of the biggest box office successes of the year and indeed of Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs career.

I‚Äôve talked a lot so far about how lines can create harmony and balance in a shot. Harmonious compositions of lines in a shot usually follow a consistent pattern and direction and are effective in quieter, calmer shots of a movie, like the opening shot of Psycho with the window discussed above. A composition of contrasting lines, following many directions and even changing drastically during a shot create energy and intensity. They can even be used to heighten the sense of disorder, confusion and chaos. Like during a violent shower stabbing perhaps.

The sequence is bookended by two simple shots of a running shower (1,7). The lines are obvious to see and create a sense of balance and restoration of order around the shots of the murder. One of my all-time favorite shots in any movie is the shot at (2). The shot is slightly oddly framed at the beginning, the right hand side of the shot is unbalanced with the water moving one way against the orientation of Marion. The empty space on the left side is more structured; the vertical lines in the shower curtain giving order and stability, stability that is broken by the blurry figure approaching through the door way.

The shot where the curtain is ripped back revealing the murderer (3) is a jarring moment of visual confusion; the lines are all over the place and the shower rail and the edge of the curtain narrow our focus to the horrifying figure wielding the knife. Horror movies make frequent use of this kind of iconic ‚Äúz-shaped‚Äù pose at their most terrifying moments as it‚Äôs visually dynamic and gives instant tension to a shot.

The subsequent, relentless, shots of the murder (4,5) are always chaotic. The water is always moving in different angles from shot to shot which never gives us a chance to orient ourselves in the moment. To be presented with so many different angles and lines so quickly is explosive and confusing.

As the murder finishes, order begins to come back to the sequence (6,7). Swirling lines of water down the plughole become more ordered over time but still contrast with each other and the edges of frame. This allows some visual interest before the final shot of the sequence; simple harmonious water lines from the showerhead.

Making the movie on paper

Alfred Hitchcock never sought to be a perfectionist. He was an experimentalist at heart, yet there was no room for improvisation in his movies. He put great effort into the preparation and planning of his shots. He storyboarded everything with his production designers and kept them to hand on set so everyone involved could see what they were collectively trying to achieve, in every shot and scene.

In doing so he could prepare each shot to have the correct lines of motion, and of meaning, to give maximum impact and create the best composition each time.

The most glaring omission in the conventional script, I believe, is camera movement.
‚Äì Alfred Hitchcock

In future blog posts, I‚Äôll try to examine more techniques of shot composition and other areas of film making from Hitchcock and other directors that explore more what makes a shot work, or not. Thanks for reading.

References

  1. Stills taken from the fantastic resource: https://the.hitchcock.zone/wiki/1000_Frames_of_Hitchcock
  2. Background information on Psycho and quotes from: Hitchcock at Work, Bill Krohn.

entry.title: Easy Barbacoa Tacos
entry.content:
This recipe is my absolute favourite way of making tacos. I seem to be having tacos at least 3 nights a week at the moment. Working from home through the Covid-19 pandemic has it‚Äôs downsides, but one of the best things about it is being able to use my slow cooker more. I can kick off something like this around lunch time and by 7-8pm I‚Äôve got dinner ready to go.

Ingredients

  • 2lb (1kg) beef chuck roast chopped up in to big cubes - any cheap slow cooking cut like short ribs, flank, stew pieces, etc will work.
  • 1 small yellow onion - sliced thin
  • 2 cloves of garlic - crushed
  • 2-3 chipotles en adobo - with some of the sauce and chopped small (I use these)
  • 1 tbsp each of Mexican chilli powder, paprika, oregano, salt, pepper - honestly whatever spices you have, just grab them all.
  • 1 cup beef broth - this stuff works well
  • 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar - this is important. It not only adds flavour but breaks down the tough meat when cooking.
  • 2 tbsp soy sauce
  • 1 tbsp of oil for frying - eg canola or sunflower.

Cooking

I start by heating the oil on high and browning the meat in a cast iron skillet. You can be quite aggressive with the browning. The more colour you put on here the more flavour you get in the slow cook later on.

While the meat is browning add the onions to the slow cooker bowl as well as the chipotles, garlic and dry spices. I tend to not fry the onions, garlic, spices etc as well as the meat. At the temperature i‚Äôm cooking the beef at they would burn too quickly.

Once the meat is well browned on all sides, add to the hot skillet the beef broth, vinegar and soy sauce. This will deglaze the pan and release all the sticky stuff in to the liquid with a bit of stirring. This only takes a 30 seconds or so, don‚Äôt let it boil and reduce too much - you want that liquid for the slow cooker.

Transfer the meat from the skillet to the slow cooker, put the lid on and leave it on low for about 7-8 hours. Don‚Äôt be tempted to lift the lid and check how it‚Äôs doing, you need to keep the heat in on slow cookers. Once done, the meat should be falling apart and you should have ~1 cup of liquid in the bowl. Use tongs and a fork to shred the meat up and stir in with the liquid which should be mostly absorbed by the beef.

Serve on heated corn tortillas with your favourite taco toppings!

entry.title: Getting Started Blogging with Hexo
entry.content:
This website is my personal blog and is intentionally minimal, lightweight and simple. (Reasons on why coming in a future blog post). It has been built with Hexo, deployed with Git and hosted on GitHub Pages. Eventually I might look in to setting up a custom URL domain and hosting elsewhere but the whole idea of this project was to keep things really simple, have an easy place to call home on the internet and publish blog posts with minimal fuss.

I researched static website generators a bit and settled on Hexo. There are other ‚Äòblog frameworks‚Äô available like Jekyll and Hugo which are well featured and supported, but I settled on Hexo for its apparent ease of use, my own familiarity with JavaScript and Markdown and a very simple deployment process which relies on nothing but a few simple terminal commands.

There are many guides to getting set up using Hexo online however in setting up this blog initially I had to gather info from various tutorials around the web and figure a few things out for myself.

This (first!) blog post attempts to bring all that knowledge together. It‚Äôs a long post but intentionally it‚Äôs just one post to keep everything together and provides, I hope, a complete guide to getting started.

Note - I am using Mac OS X as my platform of choice so bits of this guide will be specific to Mac. I imagine the set up for Linux is very similar. For Windows I imagine it‚Äôs quite similar and you can follow many of the steps, but I‚Äôm not a Windows user and so I‚Äôm afraid you‚Äôre on your own there, sorry! :)

Installing Hexo

Hexo is a ‚Äôblogging framework‚Äô which basically means it‚Äôs a bunch of tools for building simple webpages like this one. Using Node.js as a backbone, Hexo translates simple Markdown files in to well formatted HTML and bundles that together with some fancy CSS and JavaScript to create your published static webpage.

We have a bit of a ladder of installs to do here to get all we need to get going but the basic process to install Hexo is to install in the following order:

Install Homebrew

Homebrew is a package manager for OS X that makes installing all kind of tools, packages and ‚Äúlinuxy things‚Äù a breeze. I already have that installed and if you‚Äôre reading this and have an interest in this kind of think i‚Äôm pretty sure you already have that set up too so we‚Äôll skip over all the details, but as a simple reference run in a terminal:

$ /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/master/install.sh)"

You can verify it‚Äôs all OK by checking the version of Homebrew you‚Äôve just installed:

$ brew -v

Install Node.js

Node.js is a JavaScript framework that basically allows you to run JavaScript outside of a browser (eg in a Terminal). The main thing we‚Äôre getting out of this that‚Äôs useful to us right now is a tool called npm (the Node Package Manager). This is what we will use to install Hexo itself.

$ brew install node

Verify it‚Äôs all working by checking the version of npm installed:

$ npm -v

Install Hexo

With Node.js and npm installed we can finally install Hexo itself:

$ npm install hexo-cli -g

to check you‚Äôre good to go run:

$ hexo -v

Setting up first site template

Yay! We‚Äôre ready to go blogging. To kick things off, set up a new directory on disk somewhere sensible and in a terminal navigate there and run:

$ hexo init NameOfMyAwesomeBlog

This will download various bits and bobs and set up all the directory structure you need for your website. The structure will look a bit like this:

.‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _config.yml‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ node_modules‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package-lock.json‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scaffolds‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ draft.md‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ page.md‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ post.md‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ source‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _drafts‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _posts‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ about‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ themes    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ landscape

_config.yml as the name suggests is a really important file and defines a lot of the technical working of the blog. We‚Äôll edit it in a bit once we‚Äôve set up some git stuff below.

One of the beauties of Hexo is you don‚Äôt have to touch most of this stuff. You‚Äôll dig in to source a bit when creating posts and themes initially to set up the look of the pages and whenever you want to tweak things like the js or css of your site, but you shouldn‚Äôt need to do much with themes once you find one you like. We don‚Äôt even have to build or deploy the site to the web to see it in action. Hexo comes with a way to preview the webpage locally very easily. To install the server package run:

$ npm install hexo-server --save

and then:

This will host your page at http://localhost:4000 and launch your web browser with your site in its current state. The --draft flag tells hexo to view both published and draft posts (see below). If you want to preview just the actual published content to see how your site will look to the outside world when deployed and not draft posts you can remove this flag.

Installing a theme

I like a nice photo of planet Earth as much as the next person but before getting in to the process of writing posts I wanted to get a theme for my site that looked a bit better and more in keeping with the aims of this site to be simple, uncluttered and minimal. I chose Cactus by GitHub user probberechts (thanks!).

From the root of your blog directory (the directory with the _config.yml file in it) run:

$ git clone https://github.com/probberechts/hexo-theme-cactus.git themes/cactus

This will copy the theme in to the right place. Then open up _config.yml in a text editor and edit the line about theme, comment out landscape and set cactus:

# theme: landscapetheme: cactus

Cactus also comes with 4 color options: white, classic, light and dark. I chose light. Add this below where you just set the theme in _config.yml:

theme_config:  colorscheme: light

If you refresh your webpage in your browser now you won‚Äôt see the change. Anytime you edit _config.yml you need to restart the hexo server. If you rerun:

$ hexo server --draft --open

You‚Äôll see the changes and your new theme. You can dig in to the files in ./themes/cactus/ on your own to customize your page. The readme from probberechts on his Cactus theme‚Äôs GitHub page is really helpful too.

Writing first content to get going

If you‚Äôve got this far you‚Äôre probably well and truly ready to start writing posts.

Hexo has a nice system whereby you can work on drafts of posts and not have them published when you build and deploy your scene until you‚Äôre ready to, it‚Äôs a good habit to get in to. To create a post run from the root directory of your blog:

$ hexo new draft myPostName.md

This will create a post in somewhere like:

~/PATH/TO/BLOG/.../source/_drafts/myPostName.md

I won‚Äôt go in to how to write in Markdown here, you can see the cheatsheet at the bottom of this post and hundreds of other resources online for better advice on that. Markdown is a fantastically intuitive way to write for the web and I highly recommend spending some time learning how to use it. It‚Äôs really quite simple and will serve you well beyond writing posts for your blog - it can become a very efficient way of writing notes and documents in many situations.

When you‚Äôre happy with your draft you can ‚Äòpublish‚Äô the post which will move it from _drafts, a folder which doesn‚Äôt get included when you generate your site, in to _posts, which does. Run:

$ hexo publish myPostName

The ‚Äòtitle matter‚Äô of the markdown post will also get a timestamp now added with the publish date and time.

To build your site simply run the command:

You can also combine these two commands in to one if you want to run them together:

Trying a few plugins

Plugins are ways of extending the functionality of Hexo. There are hundreds available, some are very powerful and some much more niche but all add new features to your Hexo set up.

I added a search page to this site very simply. First install the search plugin:

$ npm install hexo-generator-search --save

Then create a new page for the search to live in:

$ hexo new page search

this will create a new index.md page at ./source/search/ edit this file to add the search type:

---title: Searchtype: search---

Then to configure theme‚Äôs main _config.yml (in ./themes/cactus/_config.yml in my case) to include it:

nav:  search: /search/

As another example, a simple plugin exists to be able to include emoji in your posts. Install the plugin:

$ npm install hexo-filter-github-emojis --save

This plugin needs a little bit more configuration. Edit your site‚Äôs main _config.yml file (the one at the sites root, not theme) to include:

githubEmojis:  enable: true  className: github-emoji  inject: true  styles:  customEmojis:
